repnme.cdata!:
Sustaining growth with jobs and better
            services in Turkey

abstracts.cdata!:
This result profile report focuses on
            sustaining growthmof jobs and better services in Turkey.
            From 2002 to 2006, Turkey undertook wide -ranging financial,
            economic, and public sector reforms. As a result, growth
            accelerated and public finances improved, with public debt
            in 2006 at 48 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP), down
            from 78 percent. Poverty rates declined sharply. Yet,
            sustained progress was threatened by challenges in reforming
            public finances, and outdated regulations hindered
            investments. Unemployment remained high, and the labor
            market was largely unskilled. The sharp  deterioration in
            the global economy in 2008 added to these challenges. The
            first Restoring Equitable Growth and Employment Development
            Policy Loan (REGE DPL 1) in 2010 streamlined World Bank
            support to Turkey at a critical time when unemployment was
            16 percent and GDP had contracted by 4.7 percent. The second
            Restoring Equitable Growth and Employment Development Policy
            Loan (REGE DPL 2) supports ongoing reforms of public
            finances, commercial law, and civil procedures. Turkey has
            reached almost universal health insurance coverage, enrolled
            more children in pre-school, and dramatically increased
            vocational training. These ongoing reforms are expected to
            reduce poverty and inequality in Turkey over the long run.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Competitiveness and
            Employment Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Competitiveness
            and Employment Development Policy Loan Project for the
            Turkey were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and the borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1) in a
            difficult global setting, it was important for the Bank to
            show enough creativity in designing a vehicle to provide
            continued support to the Government's reform agenda; 2)
            the importance of maintaining a policy dialogue in support
            of longer-term strategic goals should be highlighted; 3) the
            importance of combining knowledge and lending operations was
            reaffirmed; and 4) in hindsight, it would have been useful
            to include indicators that would assess performance in the
            short term.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Competitiveness and Employment
            Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Competitiveness and
            Employment Development Policy Loan (CEDPL) Project for
            Turkey were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: some
            political difficulties at the time of CEDPL inception and
            negotiations may have called for a postponement of program
            negotiations, but looking in retrospect the decision to go
            ahead was appropriate. It was well supported: a) policy
            actions-all prior actions-constituted good public policy and
            were technically and politically difficult reforms; b) these
            policies were (and still are) difficult to reverse; and c)
            clearly the relationship with the Government will have been
            unnecessarily strained if a postponement had taken place,
            particularly as the Bank had already publicly expressed
            support for these reforms. The approval of a follow-on
            operation supporting additional policy actions under the
            Government's Ninth Development Plan (NDP) validates
            this conclusion. Long time relationship with the country
            provides a good deal of knowledge and experience which has
            been taken into account when discussing with the
            authorities, designing the operation, and conducting its
            supervision. Establishing targets for indicators as specific
            as possible is of first order to monitor the program. The
            program matrix does provide a list of program outcomes and
            monitoring indicators. Many indicators are amenable to
            practical monitoring only at the end of the program. To the
            extent possible, targets should be stated more explicit in
            the program document.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Competitiveness and Employment
            Development Policy Loan

abstracts.cdata!:
The development policy loan for Turkey
            supports legal, institutional, and structural reforms that
            promote growth and the creation of more and better jobs in
            Turkey by helping maintain the currently enabling
            macroeconomic framework; improve the investment climate -
            including a large program of privatization of state owned
            enterprises (SOEs), set the foundations for overhauling
            labor market regulations in the future, (d) increase access
            to investment capital, and promote the generation of
            knowledge and innovation, the adoption of new technologies,
            and upgrading the skills of the labor force.
